awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Predicting Current-Use Pesticides and Emerging Flame Retardants in a Changing Arctic - Fate and Phototransformation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic is experiencing rapid changes such as longer ice-free seasons. One issue that must be navigated in this changing landscape is the fate of the many synthetic organic chemicals that ultimately end up in the Arctic. Little is known about the fate of these chemicals once they reach the Artic, and any of these substances can harm organisms and people. The exposure risk of these compounds is tightly coupled to their environmental fate. This research will assess the abundance of these synthetic compounds and the ability of the Arctic environment to break down these substances. To support the education of future scientists on this emerging topic, a high school module will be delivered for the Alaska Summer Research Academy on Arctic environmental chemistry. Additionally, the research groups of Jennifer Guerard and Yu-Ping Chin will recruit a teacher for the Polar TREC (Teachers and Researchers Exploring and Collaborating) Program. If successful, this project will help direct contaminant mitigation efforts that will be required in the rapidly evolving Artic landscape. 

Organic chemicals from industry and agriculture have been recently detected throughout the Arctic in the tundra, air, water, organisms, and people. However, little is known about the Artic fate of current use pesticides (CUPs) or emerging brominated flame retardants (EBFRs). This collaborative work between the University of Alaska Fairbanks and the University of Delaware seeks to understand how the Arctic's unique environment influences the fate and transformation of CUPs and EBFRs. Photolysis may play a critical role in the fate of these substances due to continuous solar irradiance in summer months coupled with the presence of dissolved organic matter (DOM).  These factors can catalyze contaminant attenuation through reaction with photo-derived reactive oxygen species (ROS) or other pathways. This project tests the hypotheses that: 1) Concentrations of CUPs and EBFRs in surface waters will be highest during and immediately following melt of snowpack; and  2) The formation of analyte-DOM complexes will render these substances more susceptible to photodegradation. The CUPs chlorpyrifos and chlorothalonil, and EBFRs 1,2-bis(2,4,6- tribromophenoxy)ethane and tetrabromobisphenol A, will be measured by atmospheric and aqueous sampling over two field seasons at Toolik Field Station. Partitioning to suspended solids, DOM, and phototransformation pathways influenced by Arctic DOM will be quantified through field and laboratory experiments. Critical measurements will be made of physical and biogeochemical parameters that can be incorporated into an Arctic-specific chemical fate model, including parameters for partitioning into environmental compartments and attenuation rates by photolytic pathways. A chemical fate model for CUPs and EBFRs in Arctic lakes will be developed to predict chemical behavior in Arctic waters under various physical and environmental conditions. Quantifying the persistence and transformation of these compounds will be indispensable for risk assessment and long-term policy development for Arctic region contaminants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Arctic is experiencing rapid climate changes, which could have profound effects on sensitive ecosystems. An often-overlooked issue in this changing landscape is the fate of synthetic organic chemicals that travel long distances through the atmosphere and ultimately end up in the Arctic. Little is known about the fate of these chemicals once they reach the Arctic, and such substances can harm wildlife and people. The exposure risk of these compounds is tightly coupled to their environmental fate, which is affected by the changing Arctic climate. The key aims of this project were to quantify atmospherically transported contaminants in the watershed of Toolik Lake and several nearby lakes located in Arctic Alaska and conduct experiments for elucidating the role of Arctic dissolved organic matter (DOM) on the environmental fate of these chemicals.

In the spring and summer of 2019 and 2022, we collected hundreds of stream, lake water, ice melt, and air samples from in and around Toolik Lake. Several classes of contaminants that travel through the atmosphere were measured in these samples, with a focus on pesticides, flame retardants, and combustion products. Samples were collected every second or third day so that high-resolution concentration changes could be captured and investigated. We were particularly interested in concentration changes occurring in early spring when snow and ice are melting since these chemicals accumulate in these matrices during winter. Dissolved organic matter (DOM) from Toolik Lake and other nearby streams and lakes was collected during 2019 and 2021. DOM properties were measured and compared to those of DOM from other freshwater sources. We then investigated how the DOM from our Arctic sites and a standard reference DOM affected contaminant fate in the Arctic.

A number of the novel brominated flame retardants we detected in the Toolik Lake watershed haven’t been detected previously in Arctic Lakes. Our results show that these chemicals are undergoing long-range atmospheric transport from other parts of the world and entering Arctic freshwater ecosystems. The concentration trends during the spring melt period and early summer indicated that precipitation is a controlling factor in their concentrations in the lake. Ratios of specific contaminant concentrations were used to determine that their source in the Toolik Lake watershed was long-range atmospheric transport and not the field station itself. We found that several legacy and current-use pesticides were frequently detected in our samples. While these chemicals have been detected previously in the arctic environment, little was known about their concentrations and fates in Arctic freshwater prior to our study. In particular, no previous studies measured their concentration changes at the high temporal resolution reported in our work. We used measured concentrations to evaluate chemical dynamics in Toolik Lake during springtime melt using a mass-balance model of inflows and outflows. We showed that there is a pulse of organic contaminants associated with springtime melt. While this pulse is not expected to significantly affect concentrations in Toolik Lake due to its large size, it is an important observation since such pulses may affect ecosystem health in smaller Arctic lake systems, streams, and un-mixed areas where melt-water drives localized high concentrations.  

Lab experiments with Artic DOM focused on its interactions with the current-use insecticide, chlorpyrifos, and the current-use brominated flame retardant, tetrabromobisphenol-A. Chlorpyrifos binding to various types of DOM isolated from the Arctic and a standard reference material (Suwannee River DOM) were measured. While chlorpyrifos readily partitioned to all studied DOMs, it exhibited stronger binding to Arctic lake DOM than Arctic stream DOM or the reference DOM. The difference in partitioning could be explained by certain measured DOM properties. The DOM affected the photodegradation of chlorpyrifos, with stark differences in photo-kinetics observed with DOM collected at different locations and times during the season. With regards to tetrabromobisphenol-A, we investigated the effects of DOM on its photodegradation rate, degradation pathways, and formation of photoproducts in artificial and natural sunlight. A pH-dependent trend in the direct photolysis rate was observed, with longer degradation times for its acidic form. DOM either played no role or slightly reduced tetrabromobisphenol-A indirect photoreactivity. Photolysis experiments conducted at our Arctic field site revealed slower than anticipated degradation, which was magnified significantly during in-lake experiments. Importantly, the type of DOM was found to influence the composition and distribution of tetrabromobisphenol-A photoproducts, suggesting that degradation pathways are affected by DOM properties. These findings provide valuable insights into the intricate interplay of environmental variables that govern the fate of atmospherically transported chemicals in aquatic ecosystems globally.
